node.title: Almudena Grandes, Novelist of Spain’s Marginalized, Dies at 61
node.alt: Almudena Grandes in 2020. She had set about writing a six-novel series focused on Spain in the aftermath of its civil war in the 1930s. She completed five volumes.
node.description: Beginning with an acclaimed erotic novel, she became what the prime minister called “one of the most important writers of our time.”
node.content: ["MADRID \u2014 Almudena Grandes, an award-winning Spanish writer and ardent feminist who shot to fame with an erotic novel about a woman rebelling against social norms, died on Nov. 27 at her home here. She was 61.", "She had been treated for cancer for over a year, her Spanish publishing house, Tusquets, said in announcing her death.", "Ms. Grandes wrote more than a dozen novels whose protagonists mostly live on the edges of traditional Spanish society, either struggling against its sexual restrictions or marginalized by poverty. She was also a left-wing activist who had set about writing a six-novel series focused on Spain in the aftermath of its civil war of the 1930s. She completed five volumes.", "Pedro S\u00e1nchez, Spain\u2019s Socialist prime minister, said on Twitter, \u201cWe lost one of the most important writers of our time.\u201d", "He added: \u201cCommitted and brave, she narrated our recent history from a progressive point of view.\u201d", "Ms. Grandes\u2019s breakthrough came in 1989 with the publication of \u201cLas edades de Lul\u00fa\u201d (\u201cThe Ages of Lulu\u201d), which tells the story of a woman\u2019s first adolescent love and how she later pursues her sexual fantasies in a Madrid that is undergoing a social transformation with Spain\u2019s return to democracy after the death of the dictator Gen. Francisco Franco in 1975.", "The novel won a literary prize for erotic fiction, sold more than a million copies worldwide and was turned into a movie by the director Bigas Luna, with a cast that included the first screen appearance of Javier Bardem, the Spanish Oscar-winning actor. Among her other books, \u201cMalena es un nombre de tango\u201d (\u201cMalena Is the Name of a Tango\u201d) and \u201cLos aires dif\u00edciles\u201d (\u201cThe Wind From the East\u201d) were also adapted for the cinema.", "Mar\u00eda de la Almudena Grandes Hern\u00e1ndez\u00a0was born on May 7, 1960, in Madrid. Her father, Manuel Grandes, had a plumbing business; her mother, Benita Hern\u00e1ndez, was a homemaker. Ms. Grandes studied geography and history, specializing in prehistory, at the Complutense University in Madrid. After completing her degree she became a contributing writer for encyclopedias and travel guides.", "Several of Ms. Grandes\u2019s novels are set during the Franco dictatorship. One of her more recent best sellers in Spain \u2014 \u201cEl coraz\u00f3n helado\u201d (\u201cThe Frozen Heart\u201d), from 2007 \u2014 starts with the funeral of a powerful businessman, attended by a mysterious woman, during which an inheritance of money and documents comes to light and helps unravel a troubled family saga dating back to the ravages of the Spanish Civil War.", "It was on the back of the success of \u201cThe Frozen Heart\u201d that Ms. Grandes started her six-novel series, set during the first 25 years of Franco\u2019s dictatorship, from 1939 to 1964. She called her project \u201cEpisodios de una guerra interminable\u201d (\u201cEpisodes in an Interminable War\u201d), akin to one of Spain\u2019s most famous literary series, the \u201cEpisodios Nacionales\u201d (\u201cNational Episodes\u201d), written by Benito P\u00e9rez Gald\u00f3s in the late 19th century.", "The first book in Ms. Grandes\u2019s series, \u201cIn\u00e9s y la alegr\u00eda\u201d (\u201cIn\u00e9s and Happiness\u201d), which was published in 2010 and won three literary prizes, tells the story of a group of left-wing guerrillas fighting Franco\u2019s forces. Last year, the fourth installment in her series, \u201cLos pacientes del doctor Garc\u00eda\u201d (\u201cThe Patients of Doctor Garc\u00eda\u201d), won the Jean Monnet Prize for European Literature, as well as the prestigious National Prize for Narrative, awarded by the Spanish culture ministry. Her last published novel and fifth installment in the series, \u201cLa madre de Frankenstein\u201d (\u201cThe Mother of Frankenstein\u201d), was released in 2020.", "In an opinion article in The New York Times in 2013, Ms. Grandes recalled the poverty as well as the dignity of many residents of Madrid in the 1960s, a time when \u201ccuriosity was a dangerous vice for Spanish children.\u201d She denounced the self-censorship that has continued to shroud Spanish society, even after its return to democracy.", "\u201cLater they told us we had to forget,\u201d she wrote, \u201cthat to build a democracy it was essential to look forward, to pretend nothing had happened. And by forgetting the bad, we also erased the good.\u201d", "Joan Tarrida, who heads another Spanish publisher, Galaxia Gutenberg, said Ms. Grandes had \u201cfollowed the great 19th-century literary tradition of highlighting social problems by creating characters with whom her readership could really connect.\u201d", "\u201cShe talked to us about our difficult recent past,\u201d he added, \u201cand gave a voice to the most vulnerable in our society.\u201d", "Ms. Grandes is survived by her husband, Luis Garc\u00eda Montero, a poet who is the director of the Cervantes Institute, the Spanish government agency that is charged with promoting and teaching Spanish worldwide; their daughter, Elisa Garc\u00eda Grandes; the couple\u2019s two other children from previous relationships, Mauro Caffarato Grandes and Irene Garc\u00eda Chac\u00f3n; and three siblings, Manuel, Gonzalo and Luli Grandes Hern\u00e1ndez.", "Mr. Garc\u00eda Montero said by phone that his wife had most recently been working on a novel (not the final installment in her series) that he called \u201can allegory of the future,\u201d dealing with a society that is struggling to maintain individual rights and freedoms after being assaulted by a pandemic.", "Ms. Grandes was a regular contributor to the Madrid-based newspaper El Pa\u00eds. She disclosed her cancer diagnosis in one of her columns in October, writing that working on the novel and maintaining her newspaper contributions was helping to keep her in good spirits.", "\u201cWriting is my life,\u201d she wrote, \u201cand never has it been more, nor as intensely as now.\u201d"]
